titleStmt.title: An Explanation of the wordes of art contained in this Booke.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: An Explanation of the wordes of art contained in this Booke.

monogr.title: Lathams falconry or The faulcons lure, and cure : in two bookes. The first, concerning the ordering and training vp of all hawkes in generall; especially the haggard faulcon gentle. The second, teaching approued medicines for the cure of all diseases in them. Gathered by long practice and experience, and published for the delight of noble mindes, and instruction of young faulconers in things pertaining to this princely art. By Symon Latham. Gent
monogr.author: Latham, Simon

keywords.term: Agriculture, viticulture, texts on hunting, veterinary science

div.head: An Explanation of the wordes of art contained in this Booke.

list.head: B
list.label: BAthing
list.item: is when you set your Hawke to the water, to wash or bath her selfe, either abroad or in the house.
list.label: Batting,
list.item: or to batte is when a Hawk fluttereth with her wings either from the pearch or the mans fist, stryuing as it were to flie away, or get liberty.
list.label: Bousing
list.item: is when a Hawke drinketh often, and seemes to be continually thirsty.

list.head: C
list.label: CReance
list.item: is a fine small long line of strong and euen twound Packthreed, which is fastened to the Hawks leash, when she is first lured.
list.label: Ceasing
list.item: is when a Hawke taketh any thing into her foot, and gripeth or holdeth it fast.
list.label: Checke or to kill,
list.item:
Checke is when Crowes, Rookes, Pies, or
other birds comming in the view of the Hawke, shee forsaketh her naturall flight to flie at them.
list.label: Casting,
list.item: is any thing that you giue your Hawk to clense her gorge with, whether it be flannell, thrummes, feathers, or such like. To cast a Hawke, is to take her in your hands before the pinions of her wings, and to hold her from bating or striuing, when you administer any thing vnto her.
list.label: Cadge,
list.item: is taken for that on which Faulconers carry many Hawkes, together when they bring them to sell.

list.head: D
list.label: DRopping
list.item: is when a Hawke muteth directly downeward, in seuerall drops, and ierketh it not longwaies from her.
list.label: Disclosed,
list.item: is when young Hawkes are newly hatch't, and as it were disclosed from their shels.

list.head: E
list.label: ERie
list.item: is the nest or place where a Hawke buildeth and bringeth vp her young ones, whether in woods, rockes, or any other places.
list.label: Endew,
list.item: is when a Hawke digesteth her meat, not onely putting it ouer from her gorge, but also cleansing her pannell.

list.head: G
list.label: GOrge,
list.item: is that part of the Hawke which first receiueth the meat, and is called the Craw or crop in other fowles.
list.label: Gurgiting,
list.item: is when a Hawke is stuft or sufforated with any thing, be it meat or otherwise.

list.head: I
list.label: INke,
list.item: whether it be of Partridge, fowle, doues, or any other pray, is the necke from the head to the body.
list.label: Intermew'd
list.item: is from the first exchaunge of a Hawkes coat, or from her first mewing, till shee come to bee a white Hawke.
list.label: Iesses,
list.item: are those short straps of leather, which are fastned to the Hawks legs, & so to the lease by varuels, anlets, or such like.

list.head: L
list.label: LVer
list.item: is that whereto Faulconers call their young Hawkes by casting it vp in the aire, being made of feathers and leather in such wise that in the motion it lookes not vnlike a fowle.
list.label: Lease
list.item: or leashe is a small long thong of leather, by which the Faulconer holdeth his Hawke fast, folding it many times about their fingers.
list.label: Lice,
list.item: are a small kind of white vermin, running amongst the feathers of the Hawke.

list.head: M
list.label: MVting
list.item: is the excrements or order which comes from Hawkes, and containeth both dunge and vrine.
list.label: A Make-hawke
list.item: is an old staunche flying Hawke, which being inur'd to her flight, wil easily instruct a younger Hawk to be waining in her pray.
list.label: Managing,
list.item: is to handle any thing with cunning according to the true nature thereof
list.label: Mew,
list.item: is that place, whether it be abroad or in the house where you set downe your Hawke, during the time that shee raseth her feathers.
list.label: Mites,
list.item: are a kind of vermine smaller then Lice, and most about the heads and nares of Hawkes.

list.head: P
list.label: PLumming,
list.item: is when a Hawke ceaseth a fowle, and pulleth the feathers from the body.
list.label: Plummage
list.item: are small downie feather which the Hawke takes, or are giuen her for casting.
list.label: Pelt,
list.item: is the dead body of any fowle howsoeuer dismembred.
list.label: Pill,
list.item: and pelfe of a fowle, is that refuse and broken remaines which are left after the Hawke hath beene releiued.
list.label: Plume
list.item: is the generall colour or mixtures of feathers in a Hawke, which sheweth her constitution.
list.label: Pearch,
list.item: is any thing whereon you set your Hawke, when shee is from your fist.
list.label: Pray,
list.item: is any thing that a Hawke killeth, and feedeth her selfe thereupon.
list.label: Pannell,
list.item: is that part of the Hawke next to the fundament whither the Hawke disgesteth her meat from her body.

list.head: Q
list.label: QVarrie,
list.item: is taken for the fowle which is flowne at, and slaine at any time, especially when young Hawkes are flowne thereunto.

list.head: R
list.label: RVfter-hood
list.item: is the first hood whieh a Hawke weareth, being large, wide, and open behind.
list.label: Reclaiming
list.item: is to tame, make gentle, or to bring a Hawke to familiaritie with the man.
list.label: Raised in flesh,
list.item: is when a Hawke growes fat, or prospereth in flesh.
list.label: Ramage
list.item: is when a Hawke is wild, coy, or disdainfull to the man, and contrary to be reclaimed.

list.head: S
list.label: SLiming,
list.item: is when a Hawke muteth from her longwaies in one intire substance, and doth not drop any part thereof.
list.label: Stooping,
list.item: is when a Hawke being vpon her wings at the height of her pitch, bendeth violentlie downe to strike the fowle or any other pray.
list.label: Summ'd
list.item: is when a Hawke hath all her feathers, and is fit either to be taken from the Crie or Mew.
list.label: Setting downe,
list.item: is when a Hawke is put into the Mew.
list.label: Sore-hawke,
list.item: is from the first taking of her from the eiry, till shee haue mewed her feathers.

list.head: T
list.label: TRussing
list.item: is when a Hawke raseth a fowle aloft, and so descendeth downe with it to the ground,

list.head: V
list.label: VNsumm'd
list.item: is when a Hawkes feathers are not come forth, or els not com'd home to their full length.

list.head: VV
list.label: VVEathering
list.item: is when you set your Hawke abroad to take the aire, either by day or night, in the frost, or in the sunne, or at any other season.
